description-en: A Hindu religious poster showing light skinned Mandodari, the wife of Ravana, outside a temple giving alms to a dark skinned man. She is wearing jewellery- nose studs, anklets, necklace and bangles and flowers in her hair. She also holds offerings for the temple in a plate in her left hand. Behind her a temple can be seen. (sp)

explanatory comments/crosstagging: Ravi Varma painted numerous narrative scenes based on classical Sanskrit literary sources, such as the epics Mahabharata and Ramayana. A good example is the poster of Mandodari, chief wife of the demon Ravana, in a scene drawn from the story of Rama. Varma imagines the beautiful demoness as a light-skinned human woman, modestly wrapped in a burnt-orange sari, stepping out of a Shaiva temple to give alms to an emaciated dark-skinned beggar. Eyes half-closed, Mandodari looks downwards towards the seated supplicant. Varma domesticates the queen of the Rakshasas as a pious South Indian housewife. Ravi Varma also designed a number of iconic depictions of the Hindu deities, where the gods present themselves more directly to the viewer. (Richard H. Davis)(gs)
explanatory comments/crosstagging: Mandodari keeps her hands at a distance from the man while giving him alms perhaps to denote the difference in their castes. (sp)
explanatory comments/crosstagging: The temple architecture in the background looks south Indian. The entrance to the building where Mandodari is standing also looks like a temple. (sp)
explanatory comments/crosstagging: The original design dates back to c. 1900. (sg)
